title.title: Papiers d'Etienne Formont relatifs à un essai de traduction française d'un fragment tibétain

repository.orgName: Bibliothèque nationale de France. Département des Manuscrits

msContents.summary: Tibétain 470 is a notebook containing a later copy of two translations of a Tibetan fragment, discovered in a ruined monastery in Siberia towards the end of the 17th century or the onset of the 18th. This fragment was subsequently presented to Emperor Peter the Great, who forwarded it to the French Academy in Paris, where it was translated into Latin by Michel Fourmont using a Latin-Tibetan dictionary from the Royal Library. However, Fourmont's translation was egregiously inaccurate, and subsequent renditions were not without flaws—a reality later underscored by H. H. Wilson in an 1832 article. In this same article, Wilson introduced a more refined English translation by the renowned Sándor Kőrösi Csoma (1784-1842). The Tibétain 470 manuscript includes the first page of Fourmont's interlineal Latin translation followed by a French translation of the Latin rendering, said to be the work of Fourmont together with his brother Étienne. The original Tibetan text, with interlineal transcription, is included on what seems to be a separate leaf inserted at the back of the notebook. Given the scarcity of Tibetan texts in Europe during that era, this fragment gained prominence among intellectuals from the early 18th to the 19th century, even serving as a seminal ‘textbook’ for Tibetan learners.
